Message.Title: On Dec 3 I posted that I screwed up by buying Apple products. I was TOTALLY WRONG. They are AWESOME!!
Message.Msg: It took a few days to figure them out because they were a little different from what I was used to but there is NO WAY I would ever go back. Some of the improvements were subtle at first but every day I learn more ways that my iPhone is better than the blackberry I had before. Also, the MacBook I have is so far ahead of the Dell that I had before that it's ridiculous. I will NEVER buy anything other than an Apple going forward unless something changes drastically. My ONLY complaint is that Apple has not pushed their computers into the work place. They cost a little more but you will make up your money many times over by paying tech geeks to repair your machines A LOT less often. Those guys typically charge about 100 bucks per hour so it doesn't take long to make up the difference in machine cost. Also, not having down time, having increased production, etc makes the Apple machines A LOT more attractive for a business environment. My family now has three iPhone 5s, one iPhone 4, one iPad, and three MacBooks. A year ago we had two iPhone 3s and one MacBook. I suspect that lots of other families are making similar transitions. Unfortunately I just bought several new Dells for my business but that's the last time that will happen. I will probably wait a year or two to try to justify my investment in the Dells but they too will be replaced by Apples at some point.

Topic.Title: Apple Time Machine - Best Article Ever

Message.Msg: The Market Wants Apple to Unveil a Time Machine by Dan Pallotta | 12:59 PM January 16, 2013 Comments (90) If you want a brilliant lesson in focus and discipline, watch Tim Cook right now. Some investors are dissatisfied with Apple. I think it's more a case of their being dissatisfied with their own lives and expecting that Apple's next product will fix everything. The constant refrain is that Apple has not introduced a disruptive product since Steve Jobs passed away. It's as if they want Apple to unveil a happiness device and they won't be happy until it does. Some people are saying that Tim Cook just ain't up to it, that he's no Steve Jobs. One commenter on a popular Apple rumor site made a multi-point list of Tim Cook's failings: 1) missed earnings for several quarters, 2) a volatile stock price, 3) quality control problems, 4) lack of new advertising, 5) bad product reviews, 6) lack of an iMac or iPad mini with a retina display, and 7) complaints that the company is getting stale and top execs are fleeing. What the naysayers are overlooking or ignoring is that one could have made a list for Steve Jobs that would look remarkably similar: Missed earnings: Apple posted a $247 million quarterly loss (in 2001, four years after Jobs took over — and the stock went UP in after-hours trading). Volatile stock: In 2008, under Jobs, the stock price dropped by more than 50%. Bad quality control: MobileMe, antenna-gate No advertising innovation: The "I'm a Mac/"I'm a PC" campaign ran for three and a half years without a refresh. Nothing on the scale of "Think different" was created by Jobs more than a decade after that iconic campaign. Bad product reviews: One word: Ping. Also, Consumer Reports issued a "does not recommend" on the iPhone 4 (in 2010). No iPad mini at all. Executive exodus: In 2008, Tony Fadell, senior vice president of the iPod division, stepped down. His wife, the VP of HR at Apple, also left. In 2004, Apple's CFO, Fred Anderson, left the company. Apple's General Counsel, Nancy Regina Heinen, left in 2006. (In 2007, the SEC filed charges alleging that she let Apple backdate large option grants and altered corporate records to hide the actions. She settled with the SEC without admitting or denying the charges.) Sounds to me like Tim Cook isn't the only one who's had to deal with shuffling in the top ranks. So Tim Cook has not introduced any disruptive new products in his first year. But bear in mind that four years elapsed from the time Steve Jobs took back the reins until the iPod was introduced. Six years elapsed between the introduction of the iPod and the iPhone. Six years without a disruption under Steve Jobs. During that time, we had to endure the unveiling of flops and iterations like the iPad Hi-Fi, leather iPod pouches, and the iPod Photo. Yes, Steve Jobs actually unveiled a leather iPod pouch on stage. That was an underwhelming day. Another three years went by without a disruption until the iPad was unveiled — and at the time, many didn't view it as a disruption at all. "It's just a bigger iPhone," they said, not understanding the gigantic implications of a bigger iPhone, in much the same way that they cannot now understand how a slightly smaller iPad will change everything. We don't know what Apple has in store for us. Over the past 10 years, it reinvented the telephone, music players, the way we consume music, and mobile computing itself — actually, with the iPad, Apple invented mobile computing. Apple can ride the wave of those disruptions for a little while. It has changed the world. It is now selling the products that define that new world to the world. Even if it has nothing more up its sleeve than beautiful new iterations of its existing products, the fact remains that this is a company that last quarter had profits of more than $8 billion. Compare that with Amazon's performance: Amazon lost $247 million in its last quarter. Amazon's price-to-earnings ratio is now 2,767. Apple's is 13. And Apple's profits are growing substantially year over year. There are other markets waiting to be disrupted, for sure. Television. Automobiles. Housing. Higher education (Apple is already on its way to transforming that with iBooks Author and the iPad). If Apple is to maintain the level of success it's achieved in the past 15 years, it may need to enter those industries in the next 15. And it probably will. But for now, Apple is like no other company on the planet, based simply on what it has achieved in the last six years. Tim Cook is capitalizing on the potential of those years of disruption, and is doing it masterfully. The critics that are screaming right now are intellectually lazy. They're throwing temper tantrums instead of looking at the big picture. Like two-year-olds, they don't really know what they want. And they're not happy when they get it, anyway. Apple could unveil a new car and they'd say Apple's days are over because it's just bet its future on an industry it knows nothing about. Not unlike, say, Apple's entrance into the mobile phone industry. I bet that if Apple did unveil a time machine, they'd claim it wasn't fast enough. Tim Cook is taking exactly the right approach, staying the course, despite distracting expectations swirling around him. Apple is a marvel of human achievement. Why waste the beautiful sight of it by casting your gaze on a group of misbehaving children who have never accomplished anything remotely close to it in concept or scale and don't have the faintest understanding of how something this remarkable operates and grows in the first place?

Message.Title: 527 is the number to watch tomorrow
Message.Msg: If 480 was the important number Tuesday, then 527 is the one to watch Thursday with one eye keeping 481 in it's peripheral view. The minor trend is created by connecting 9/21/12, and 1/2/13 this should be around 527 tomorrow, breaking above that could signal our breakout we've been waiting for. Break out of what? Glad you asked, the major trend is formed by connecting 3/6/09, and 11/25/11, and should be around 481 tomorrow. We will bounce between those line of resistence, and support until it finally breaks out to one side or the other. Here's what's really cool, Friday through today started the formation of an inverse head and shoulders pattern. Getting over 510 tomorrow should confirm the right shoulder, and sets us up to acheive 533+, well above the minor trend. Also supporting this move is the 520.30 gap from Monday to be filled. I feel good about breaking 520 tomorrow, when we do I'll be closly watching 527 area, because that could be the signal to run to the mid 530's. The alternative is 481, another volitile day ahead.

Message.Msg: Obama's actions are Disgusting! The Texas Governer Rick Perry also agrees with me. Gov. Rick Perry released the following statement regarding President Obama's executive actions: "The Vice President's committee was appointed in response to the tragedy at Newtown, but very few of his recommendations have anything to do with what happened there. "Guns require a finger to pull the trigger. Topic.Title: LEGENDARY TIMER ON AAPL DEMARK: "THE BOTTOM IS IN" AND 20% RALLY COMING

Message.Msg: The key with Demark's call here is that he has the convergence of multiple indicators all saying the same thing, just like his call on the Shanghai Index this past December where he called the bottom to the day and it has bounced hard since then. You can also look at Herbalife (HLF) where he called a bottom at $25 and said it would bounce to $55 and it's up to $45 already. He's not always right, but he is almost always right it seems when he has multiple indicators all saying the same thing. That's why he asked to go on FM. It's good for his business to publicly draw attention to calls he is highly confident in being right on. Also, it was very interesting to see the respect all on the FM panel showed him. No one else could go on FM, call a bottom on Apple, say the stock is bouncing to $600 in a couple of weeks from $484 when it was down in the pre-market, and not have a single person show him disbelief. In fact, one person cited that the problem with technical analyses is they identify forks in the road. The thing about Demark's indicators is that they tell you which path to take. Finally, there is a lot of big money that listens to Demark. They were sellers and shorts at $701 when he called the top. And, part of the reason it went to $494 is they stayed out. With some big money getting back in and selling exhausted (according to Demark), it's a nice set-up for a rally with any reasonable q1 report next week. GLTA

Message.Title: Debt Ceiling Theatrics Could Spark 10% Sell-Off
Message.Msg: Hugh Johnson of Johnson Advisors says the debate itself, along with the potential for spending cuts deep enough to cut economic growth, are reasons for concern. Johnson says the smart play for traders going into the heart of the debate next month is to be on the short side of the market. For those less inclined to jump in and out of the tape, Johnson suggests dragging their feet on buying stocks unless or until stocks pullback around 10%.

Topic.Title: Gap Up At Open Will Be Bad For Longs..

Message.Msg: Gaps don't have to fill, and no market law dictates that they will. Chart guys pretend to be soothsayers pointing out gaps months/years in the past trying to stir up fear because "most gaps always fill"...that is like a definite maybe. The reason gaps fill is because of the regular ebb/flow of the market, if it were true that all gaps fill I guess I'll see you at $23, $41, and $138...And if/when the market would crash and fill those gaps it would have nothing to do with the gap itself

Message.Title: JUDGE AGREES TO ADD MORE SAMSUNG PRODUCTS TO AAPL'S CLAIM
Message.Msg: RECALL THE HTC SETTLEMENT (~ $12/DEVICE ROYALTY TO AAPL) AND NOTE THIS IS ANOTHER FEDERAL CIRCUIT JUDGE -- NOT THE SAME ONE WHO AWARDED AAPL $1.2B FROM SAMSUNG (WHICH IS ON APPEAL BY SAMSUNG WITH POST-JUDGEMENT INTEREST RUNNING)... WE THINK THESE CASES WILL ALL END BEAUTIFULLY FOR AAPL, AND SAMSUNG WILL BE RELIEVED TO PAY ONLY A $12 OR SO ROYALTY PER DEVICE LIKE HTC WILL BE DOING. Wednesday, January 16, 2013, 08:06 pm Judge agrees to add newly released Apple and Samsung devices to upcoming trial By Mikey Campbell A California federal judge on Wendesday agreed with additional stipulations filed jointly by Apple and Samsung in which each party sought to supplement its case in an upcoming trial slated to begin in 2014. Samsung's Galaxy S III mini has been dropped from Apple's suit. | Source: Samsung The order on the parties' amended joint stipulations, handed down by Magistrate Judge Paul Grewal, adds a number of new devices to the case and withdraws one as a result of court filings from November 2012. The filing is part of Apple's Galaxy Nexus case and is not to be confused with the Apple v. Samsung court trial which ended in August. As stated in the stipulation, Apple adds the Galaxy Note II, Galaxy S III with Android 4.1, Rugby Pro, Galaxy Tab 8.9 Wi-Fi and Galaxy Tab 2 10.1 to the case while Samsung tacks on the iPhone 5. The Galaxy S III mini was on the list of devices alleged to have infringed Apple's utility patents, but assertions against the device were dropped after Samsung reported that it was not actively importing or selling the handset in the U.S. With the Galaxy Nexus trial so far out -- currently scheduled to begin on March 31, 2014 -- there will likely be more devices added and further disputes filed before the fact discovery process is completed in July of this year.

Message.Msg: More on Apple: 1) KGI Securities' Ming-Chi Kuo, an accurate source of iPhone 5 and iPad Mini scoops last year, claims the 5th-gen regular iPad will be "significantly lighter and slimmer" than the 4th-gen model. But he doesn't see it arriving until Q3, around the same time as a new iPad Mini and an iPhone 5S. An Apple TV refresh is forecast for Q1, and a MacBook Air refresh for Q2. 2) Apple has begun offering 2-year installment plans to Chinese iPhone/MacBook buyers. The 16GB iPhone 5 currently goes for $840 unsubsidized in China.

Message.Title: JPMorgan Trims Apple (AAPL) PT to $725; cut earnings to $13
Message.Msg: If you're into upside surprises when company's report quarterly results, Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL) was generally your reliable go-to. However, according to one firm, that all might change this quarter. J.P. Morgan analyst Mark Moskowitz says that iPhone sales aren't the concern for Apple in the quarter. What the firm is worried about is iPad shipments. On the iPhone 5, Moskowitz notes that "supply chain adjustments likely are related to Apple pulling back on double ordering of components as a result of manufacturing yield improvements." The firm has an estimate of 47.9 million iPhone shipments in the quarter. Looking further ahead, the firm reduces March-quarter shipments from 45 million to 43 million, citing lighter-than-expected euro-zone sales. On iPad shipments, Moskowitz thinks that supply chain constraints could come in here. He comments, "Our research indicates that near-term supply constraints impacted iPad sell-in activity through the end of November." The firm is cutting iPad shipment estimates from 20.1 million down to 18.4 million. Moskowitz contends that the recent drop in Apple's stock price stems from funds rebalancing the weight of Apple in their portfolios. he notes that it is difficult to "defend a stock where gross margin declines were expected in the coming year." However, he believes that iPhone order cuts imply that manufacturing yields and gross margin will be on the rebound. J.P. Morgan sees the smartphone market growing 30.5 percent in calendar 2013 and expect that Apple will be able to maintain 28.6 percent shipment growth. The firm commented, "Over time, we expect Apple to have the opportunity to harvest more profits in smartphones, especially as the European wireless carriers build out LTE networks in the next 12-18 months. The build out of LTE networks in the U.S. has been strong, but Europe has been lagging." What does this mean for the quarter? J.P. Morgan is modeling EPS of $13 and revenue of $52.01 billion. Mac shipments of 5.18 million and iPod shipments of 14.01 million. Moskowitz cut its price target from $770 down to $725, keeping an Overweight rating.

Message.Title: Apple can't raise dividends here is why - good article in Forbes
Message.Msg: It would be hard not to know that Apple’s shares have gotten crushed over the past four months ($702 on September 19) and since the start of the year ($532 on December 31) to $505. While the dividend yield is now 2.1% and there are a number of articles about how much it could (or should be) raised one needs to take a look at US based cash and investments and US generated cash to determine how much Apple may raise its dividend. Payout ratios are almost irrelevant if you don’t know how much US cash there is. First, I believe that Apple won’t rush into any decisions (remember how long it has taken management to re-start a dividend and share buyback program). I believe they are on a path to increase it over time vs. making a big increase. Second, since dividends and stock buybacks can only be done with US based cash one needs to understand what those numbers are. Below is a table with Apple’s 2011 and 2012 year end reported balance sheets and my projection for September 2013. From the 10K’s you can determine how much cash is US based which was $27.3 billion in 2011 and $38.7 billion in 2012 or an increase of $11.4 billion. For 2013 I estimate that US based cash will increase by $11.5 billion (about flat with the previous year) and that its dividend payments ($10.1 billion) and stock buybacks ($3.3 billion) will use all the US cash generated in 2013. Therefore for Apple to increase its dividend it would have to start using some of the $36.8 billion remaining in the US ($38.7 billion on September 2011 minus the $1.9 billion needed for 2013’s dividends and buybacks). Or it could borrow money which I don’t see the company doing.

Message.Title: BMO Capital Slashes Apple Top-Line & Bottom Line Estimates Cuts Target
Message.Msg: January 17, 2013 8:54 AM EST BMO Capital's Keith Bachman is the latest analyst to cut his price target on Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL). Today he cut his target from $670 to $640 and lowered March quarter and forward estimates, but kept an Outperform rating. Bachman believes near-term guidance could disappoint. Commenting on speculation of a low-priced iPhone, Bachman said Apple should attempt to broaden its market reach with such a device, although it could be tricky. The analyst notes that at present, the $300 to $400 price smartphone market represents about 10% of industry units shipped. "Therefore, to be successful, we believe that Apple will need to grow the size of the mid-range category and pull new users up from lower-end competitor phones, while not cannibalizing its existing user base of high-end phones," he said. If Apple does offer a new low-end iPhone in CY2013, investors will need to digest margin dilution even as operating income and EPS increase, according to the analyst. That said, he thinks management could increase both dividends and buybacks in CY2013, and believes that the current valuation is compelling, particularly when compared to their projected growth opportunities. The firm lowered Q213 EPS from $12.30 to $11.41, Q3 from $10.58 to $9.32 and Q4 from $10.64 to $8.67. FY213 EPS was cut from $48.47 to $45.25. FY2014 EPS estimate from $57.85 to $55.50.

Message.Title: Apple's Earnings Report: I believe this blogger Options2Wealth may be on to something
Message.Msg: Couple of days back I came across this blogger, Options2Wealth on Seeking Alpha. He wrote a post kinda long but detailed that makes a lot of sense to me. This is the post in its entirety. I have removed a number of links in his post to make sure that Yahoo does not flag my post: Apple's Chief Executive Officer Is Now Also Leaker-In-Chief [Edit or Delete] 0 comments Jan 13, 2013 1:34 PM | about stocks: AAPL This past week, Apple's CEO, Tim Cook was in China... In an interview with the local media, Sina Tech, Cook revealed that he met with the Mr. Xi Guohua, head of China's largest mobil service provider, China Mobile Ltd. Incidentally, unlike Mainland China's other mobil service providers, the behemoth China Mobile does not offer the iPhone as part of its subscriber packages to its 700 million customers. Geez, their subscriber base is 2x the size of the entire US population... A spokesman for China Mobile confirmed to CNBC that the talks took place, and said the two sides discussed "matters of cooperation." No further details were given, as a confidentiality agreement was reportedly signed. Let me put this news in some context... Apple's stock has been in somewhat of a freefall the past few months, having dropped almost 30% from its September 2012 high of $705. Cook is under a lot of pressure from Apple shareholders to stop the slide...So for him to be in China in the same week as the CES in Las Vegas and 2 weeks before Apple announces its first quarter, 2013 earnings, is, in my humble opinion, quite significant... Being a history buff, I also like to take my cues from history books whenever I can to gain an advantage in the markets...I remember all too well how evasive the former US Secretary of State, Henry Kissinger was, especially with the press, when he made the secret trip to China 40+ years ago to meet China's Chairman Mao and Premier Zhou EnLai...

Message.Title: Apple's Earnings Report: I believe this blogger Options2Wealth may be on to something (Part 2)
Message.Msg: In other words, when leaders representing important countries, or for that matter important companies, are in the midst of delicate negotiations that could have far reaching implications for their respective nations or businesses, they keep those discussions secret. They certainly don't want to embarrass themselves should their talks fail. So for someone as important as Tim Cook, whose stature in today's business world is no different than the stature(s) Henry Kissinger and Richard Nixon enjoyed 40 years year ago on the political stage, goes to China and then of his own free volition, leaks to the press that he met with the head of China's largest mobil telecommunications company, I cannot help but believe that he must have an agreement in his pocket for him to leak the news of his meeting with Chairman Guohua. If the above is not enough proof, in yet another interview, this time to China's Xinhua News Agency, Cook was quoted as saying, "China is currently our second largest market. I believe it will become our first. I believe strongly that it will." I also find it interesting that China Mobile's spokesman, when confronted with Cook's leak, admitted that his boss met with Apple's CEO. This spokesman then goes on to reveal that the 2 companies have signed a confidentiality agreement...hmmm... And, let's not forget, that on Thursday, January 11th, Apple stock was up more than $11 on more than 2 million shares traded in pre-market...That's more than $1 billion in buying! I am betting that the reason for that frenzied buying was that the news of an impending agreement between Apple and China Mobile had leaked out... I believe that Apple will announce the news of the agreement on Monday, January 21st along with their first quarter results.

Message.Title: JP Morgan Slashes iPad Q1 Sales 10% Today: Confirms Japan's Nikkei News Research
Message.Msg: Pricing Main Factor as Nexus 7 Outpaces iPad Mini Sales in Japan (GOOG) (AAPL) January 17, 2013 9:21 AM EST Google's (Nasdaq: GOOG) Nexus 7 tablet is a lot of things, but it's no Apple (Nasdaq: AAPL) iPad mini. And that's just the way Japan likes it. According to Japan's Nikkei news wire, the Nexus 7 is outpacing iPad mini sales in Japan. The survey, conducted by BCN in December, asked 2,4000 consumer electronics stores what sales were like. Results showed that the Nexus 7 took 44.4 percent of the tablet market, while the iPad mini nabbed just 40.1 percent. Pricing was one of the big draws, according to BCN, was pricing. The Nexus 7 comes in at about $100 less than the least-expensive version of the iPad mini. As might be expected, the data wasn't entirely clean. BCN noted that a shortage in iPad mini supply may have contributed to some sales losses, though the firm believes the price difference would have kept the Nexus 7 ahead anyway. Shares of Apple and Google are indicated higher Thursday.

Topic.Title: SAMSUNG is the present and future

Message.Msg: I had a good and in-depth look at the Samsung GS3 yesterday (owned by my friend who by the way is unimpressed and dumping it shortly) and compared it closely to my iPhone 5 in operation. I had no doubt at the end of the process that the GS3 was a substandard and over-hyped product, glitzy looking at first impression but way behind the iPhone 5 in terms of speed, precision, smoothness, simplicity, sharpness, color, etc., etc. If the evidence of the enormous iPhone 5 demand in the December quarter (in the west, in China, and note this: even in Samsung’s Korea) is anything to go by, then frankly the consumer around the globe in my opinion still perceives the iPhone as a more coveted product than Samsung's GS3 and other Androids. Actually in China the GS3 is seen as an insult if given as a gift. They all want the iPhone.

Topic.Title: Apple's Earnings Report: I believe this blogger Options2Wealth may be on to something (Part 2)

Message.Msg: Both firms need each other. CM is not hemorrhaging all customers to China Unicom and China Telecom, rather CM is only losing out on the higher-income customers who can afford to pay more for 3G and 4G service and IPHONE. But those are the more profitable customers, CM naturally doesn't wish to lose. Apple also needs CM lets not forget as Apple is losing market share in China to Samsung by Apple not having its products sold thru the largest carrier in China. So this is a "win win" deal for both Apple and CM to work Cooperatively together, both will profit. And it makes sense Apple would make a new lower cost phone to run on CM's proprietary network, and in return CM would commit to buy a very large quantity of these phones... and Apple would use its huge overseas cash-reserves to offer financing at low rates to CM's customers for these contracts. It all makes sense and all should do well from it.

Message.Title: Plain and Simply Apple Has Stopped Growing Earnings
Message.Msg: Plain and Simply Apple (AAPL) Has Stopped Growing Earnings January 16, 2013 3:35 PM EST Shares of Apple (NASDAQ: AAPL) are down 30 percent since its September high, leaving many investors scratching their heads. However if you look at the most fundamental metric of any growth company the decline may be perfectly justified. The plain and simple fact is Apple's earnings have stopped growing... dead. For the upcoming quarter (Q113), for example, EPS is expected to drop about 4% to $13.35 per share. Last year the company posted EPS of $13.87. If you compare this quarter's EPS growth to past quarters you can quickly see the red flag. In Q412 Apple posted EPS growth of 23%... in Q312 it was 20%... in Q212 it was 92%... in Q112 it was 116%. The drop-off is so glaring it is blinding. On the top-line, Apple is still showing growth, although that is also slowing dramatically. Revenue this quarter is expected to grow 18%. In last year's Q1 revenues grew 73%. Apple is still a wonderful company and likely undervalued on various metrics. However if you ask the very fundamental question - "Is Apple growing earnings?" The answer is a big fat NO. It appears the law of large numbers has finally caught up with the company. Smart investors noticed and took a hike. Apple is scheduled to post earnings on January 23rd, after the market closes.

Message.Title: Investment banks see 50 million iPhones sold in Q4
Message.Msg: Wednesday, January 16, 2013, 05:45 pm, $1,111 target for AAPL shares By Kevin Bostic Researchers at Piper Jaffray expect that Apple will reveal during its quarterly conference call next week that it sold some 50 million iPhones for the quarter ending in December, five million more units than the firm previously estimated, while Topeka Capital Markets sees positive indicators for AAPL and set a price target of $1,111 for the stock. After seeing a decline over the past month, Apple stock gained $20.17 (4.15%) on Wednesday to close at $506.09. | Chart via Reuters In a quarterly preview, analyst Gene Munster of Piper Jaffray predicts that Apple will surpass the firm's earlier December quarter estimates by five million units based in part on "commentary from AT&T suggesting iPhone sales expanded slightly [year-over-year] and [from] Verizon that iPhone helped it reach record activations in December." Munster estimates roughly 15 million iPhones could have been sold in the U.S., with a possible global sales range of 41 to 54 million units. Munster also reduces the estimate for iPhones sales for the upcoming March 2013 quarter by five million to 38 million units. The firm expects that Apple's forthcoming guidance will shed light on recent reports of component order cuts. Piper also expects Apple to announce 25 million iPad sales for the December quarter, with 20 million full-size iPads sold alongside five million iPad minis. Mac sales will likely see a drop of seven percent year-over-year, with Apple selling 4.8 million Macs over the last three months of 2012. Topeka Capital: Apple risk-reward "extremely attractive Analysts at Topeka Capital Markets remain upbeat on AAPL despite negative sentiment surrounding the stock. In a report released Wednesday -- titled "Apple's Brightest and Most Innovative Days are Ahead of It" -- analyst Brian White said the firm believes Apple's product portfolio "has never been stro

Message.Title: ABI Research: iPhone market share to peak at 22 percent in 2013
Message.Msg: iPhone market share to peak at 22 percent in 2013, says analyst Summary: Could the iPhone breach the 22 percent market share 'peak,' as set by one analysts' firm, if Apple hit the enterprise sector harder? By Zack Whittaker for Between the Lines | January 17, 2013 -- 15:59 GMT (07:59 PST) One research firm believes that Apple's iPhone market share will peak at 22 percent, and that it will hit that ceiling this year -- and then remain flat thereon in. Despite predictions that smartphone shipments will account for half of all handset shipments by 2014, and a steady rise to 2.4 billion shipments by 2014: "Barring an unlikely collapse in Samsung’s business, even Apple will be chasing Samsung’s technology, software, and device leadership in 2013 through the foreseeable future," says ABI Research senior analyst Michael Morgan.

Topic.Title: Why does it seem Opex only applies to Apple? Never hear it on any other stock??

Message.Msg: AAPL is notoriously negative on OPEX (nearly every Friday). I attribute most of that to MM manipulation but I may be overreaching. It may simply be that there are so many call buyers that push the premiums higher than normal time-value would suggest based on Black-Scholes and the decline accelerates toward intrinsic on Fridays and that destabilizes the PPS. But whatever it is, rarely does AAPL perform well on Friday compared to Monday/Tuesday. Wednesday-Thursday seem less affected.

Topic.Title: What if Apple misses estimates?

Message.Msg: It is almost impossible to guess how the market will react. I, being more a trader then investor, see a knee jerk reaction either way. I dont focus on AAPL's company fundamentals because at this current point in time, IMO, the markets are trying to "gauge" the product expansion. The data to support the expansion in China is clouded and I have found no substance to support that it is growing substatially in Asia. The possiblility that AAPL has grown in China is not to be ruled out because AAPL is very strict on info that is to shared to the public. I am short biased in this economy.... which tends to bleed over into companies as well, but I cant rule out that AAPL is a great company and sells a popular product. With all this being said, I am literally betting on previous data released from AAPL that it is not going to meet street expections. I dont think it will miss big time, but the China expansion is still in the early stages and NO ONE can properly gauge the China market unless they stand in market square and take a street poll of who owns what. I am a Sociological Major, and study "fads" in society. China as a whole more or less, dont admire the US or the products we have to offer. They are literally taught to use America as a launch pad for self improvement by way of manufacturing American products at home (China) and selling it back to Americans for double or triple the productioncost with no import tax. The only reason China hasnt rocketed above all other nations is because the Chinese Govt is still very much power hungry and cant let go long enough to give the illusion of freedom.

Topic.Title: anyone know the current 1q earnings estimate???

Message.Msg: NEW YORK (AP) — Apple has a new iPhone, two new iPads and three new PCs as it heads into the holiday quarter, the biggest selling season of the year. But, paradoxically, it expects these new gadgets to bring down its profits compared to last year. The reason: the new gadgets are expensive to make, Apple executives said Thursday, and the company is not interested in cutting corners for the sake of short-term returns. On top of the holiday-quarter warning, the company reported earnings for its just-ended quarter that missed Wall Street's expectations for the second quarter in a row — something that hasn't happened in more than a decade. In part, the issues facing Apple are a normal consequence of having so many new products, said Chief Financial Officer Peter Oppenheimer. When a production line is new, it costs more to run and the components are more expensive. "The difference this time is the sheer number of products we're introducing at a short time," Oppenheimer told analysts on a call Thursday. But Oppenheimer also singled out the iPad Mini, the new, smaller version of the iPad the company unveiled Tuesday. It starts at $329, well above the $199 competitors charge for similar products. Apple's price is "aggressive," with a margin well below its other products, Oppenheimer said. "When we set out to build the iPad Mini, we didn't set out to build a small, cheap tablet, we set out to build a smaller iPad that offered the full iPad experience" Oppenheimer said. Apple expects a gross profit margin of 36 percent in the current quarter, the lowest figure in at least four years. In the holiday quarter last year, its gross margin was 44.7 percent. The gross margin represents what Apple gets from selling its products, minus the cost of making them. It ignores the cost of research and development, marketing and corporate overhead.... (more)

Topic.Title: anyone know the current 1q earnings estimate???

Message.Msg: On the same call, CEO Tim Cook justified the projected profit drop to Wall Street in similar terms. "We're unwilling to cut corners in delivering the best product experience in the world," he said. "We're managing the company for the long run." Apple launched the iPhone 5 a month ago. This week, it unveiled the iPad Mini and an upgraded full-size iPad, plus a new MacBook laptop and two desktop Macs. Apple said it expects earnings of $11.75 per share in the holiday quarter, below the $13.87 per share it earned in the same period last year. Apple routinely lowballs its estimates, but this time the forecast was further from the analyst estimate than usual. Analysts polled by FactSet were expecting earnings of $15.59, on average. Apple expects sales of $52 billion, roughly in line with the analyst expectation of $56 billion, considering the company's conservative forecasts. Apple shares fell $6.33, or 1 percent, to $603.47, extending a downward trend for the stock, which hit an all-time high of $705.07 a month ago, on the day the iPhone 5 went on sale in the U.S. and eight countries. Apple reported its results as Microsoft Corp. was set to launch Windows 8 on Friday, along with its first tablet computer, the Surface. Cook said that while he had not used the Surface himself, he gathered from reviews that it was a "fairly compromised, confusing product" that tries to do too many things. Part of Microsoft's message is that the Surface will double as a laptop. It's including a full version of its Office suite on the product and will be selling covers that act as keyboards. "I suppose you could design a car that flies and floats, but I don't think it would do all of those things very well," Cook said...(more) #$%$ yahoo`s new twitter word limit)

Topic.Title: anyone know the current 1q earnings estimate???

Message.Msg: A slowdown in the growth of iPad sales was a major contributor to earnings miss for the latest quarter. It wasn't completely unexpected, as the rumor mill correctly predicted that Apple would launch the iPad Mini. Cook said there's usually a slowdown in the September-ending quarter, and the 14 million iPads sold exceeded Apple's forecast. Analysts, however, had been expecting 17 million to 18 million. Sales were also hurt by slowing growth in China, after some blockbuster years. Apple's sales in China more than doubled in fiscal 2010 and 2011, but in the latest quarter, the Asia-Pacific segment grew just 15 percent, year over year. Growth in the July-September quarter was also slow in economically troubled Europe. Net income in the fiscal fourth quarter was $8.2 billion, or $8.67 per share. That was up 24 percent from $6.6 billion, or $7.05 per share, a year ago. Analysts polled by FactSet were expecting earnings of $8.84 per share. Revenue was $36 billion, up 27 percent from a year ago. Analysts were expecting $35.8 billion. The Cupertino, Calif., company sold 26.9 million iPhones in the quarter, at the high end of expectations. The launch of iPhone 5 came late in the quarter and didn't move the needle much. For the full fiscal year, Apple's net income was $41.7 billion, or $27.68 per share. That was up 61 percent from the year before. Revenue was $156.5 billion, up 46 percent.

Topic.Title: It's all about the future and everything points to decline

Message.Msg: Apple doesn't exhibit at CES. Apple's people however got to see all the incremental advances the Android phones made, and if any good ideas, Apple can put them in its own two new models of phones it is developing for launch in summer. Because of Apple's huge cash-hoard, and its large volumes of parts purchases devoted to only a few lines of phones (as opposed to Samsungs 130 phone models, mostly low and mid-cost phones), Apple can get better pricing on advanced new tech components so it can make bigger profit margins on its phones, than can HTC which makes 30 models.

Topic.Title: holding 17 of yesterdays 20 bucks..and bashers are already BACK??

Message.Msg: No, it's not all that matters. Support levels matter as we've seen for over a month. We've been in a trading range bouncing off 505. This is a critical technical support level and until this week has remained intact. Support must remain broken with follow-through for a few days with volume before it resets lower. So far that is not happening although today is an important component. If 505 holds given the attacks on Monday and Tuesday, the probabilities for a PPS recovery grow astronomically as they do every time support holds. It's tea-leaf analysis to be sure but so is all analysis to some extent. The fall from 705 took out support level after support level until 505. So far we've held and that bodes well for the PPS. That's what matters.

Message.Title: ABI Research: Apple iPhone Market Share Has Peaked Desperately Needs NFC To Survive
Message.Msg: One research firm believes that Apple's iPhone market share will peak at 22 percent, and that it will hit that ceiling this year -- and then remain flat thereon in. Despite predictions that smartphone shipments will account for half of all handset shipments by 2014, and a steady rise to 2.4 billion shipments by 2014: "Barring an unlikely collapse in Samsung’s business, even Apple will be chasing Samsung’s technology, software, and device leadership in 2013 through the foreseeable future," says ABI Research senior analyst Michael Morgan. Apple currently holds an 18.5 percent share of the U.S. mobile subscribers market, according to recent comScore figures. Samsung currently pegs in at 26.9 percent, rising by 1.2 percent in the three-months ending November... Samsung has grown significantly in market share since 2010, from mid single digit percent through to around 30 percent at its peak, depending on the market share statistics you read. The reason why Samsung has rocketed so far and so quickly is partially thanks to its availability of cheaper smartphones with a lower profit margin than Apple's, but also because it spreads its platform load across the various Android versions, but also Bada, Tizen, and Windows Phone. Samsung has also invested in newer technologies faster than Apple did in the smartphone space, by including near-field communications (NFC) technology for wireless payments, and 4G LTE networking for next-generation mobile broadband speeds.

Message.Title: Q2 guidance
Message.Msg: I must be missing something but I have no idea why analysts are expecting Q2 to be way lower than Q1. Last year Q2 was actually the better quarter if you factor out the extra week that was in Q1. The driving force in the quarter seems to be the Chinese New Year and Apple is far, far better positioned in China than they were a year ago. Remember the riots and apology by Cook for missing the demand? This year the iPhone 5 is already in stores, the Mini is the hot item and Apple is now offering credit. Q2 will be absolutely huge. Apple always sandbags but their guidance should be well above current expectations.

Message.Title: Read-David Rolfe is adding more to Wedgewood portfolio. Wishes he could buy beyond threshold!
Message.Msg: David Rolfe, chief investment officer at Wedgewood Partners in St. Louis, isn’t flinching at Apple’s share price drop from $700 to $500 a share. “Apple is still king of the hill,” he told The Wall Street Journal. “Rolfe said he was adding to his Apple stake during the fourth quarter and the first few weeks of 2013 as the stock tumbled. It now makes up more than 9 percent in the RiverPark/Wedgewood fund, by far the fund’s biggest weighting, and is pushing up against the firm’s maximum holding thresholds,” the Journal wrote. The fund has about $500 million in assets under management. He said he wished the fund could add even more Apple stock at those levels. Apple (AAPL) has been trading in the $506 to $510 range today.

Message.Title: Wedgewood: "Apple is King of the Hill"
Message.Msg: See WSJ article today if you haven;t cancelled your subscription to Rupert's rag yet. Wedgewood, as per the latest 13F, had some $122M of their $1.6B fund in AAPL stock as of 9/30/12, but they added some $22m of capital to the allocation as the stock dropped 4Q. Jan 17, 2013, 1:22pm CST Rolfe at Wedgewood Partners has no qualms about Apple stock Greg Edwards David Rolfe, chief investment officer at Wedgewood Partners in St. Louis, isn’t flinching at Apple’s share price drop from $700 to $500 a share. “Apple is still king of the hill,” he told The Wall Street Journal. “Rolfe said he was adding to his Apple stake during the fourth quarter and the first few weeks of 2013 as the stock tumbled. It now makes up more than 9 percent in the RiverPark/Wedgewood fund, by far the fund’s biggest weighting, and is pushing up against the firm’s maximum holding thresholds,” the Journal wrote. The fund has about $500 million in assets under management. He said he wished the fund could add even more Apple stock at those levels. Apple (AAPL) has been trading in the $506 to $510 range today.

Message.Title: Apple ‘Greed Is Good’ Should Be More Like ‘Don’t be evil’: Google denies hitting a donkey with Street View car in Botswana
Message.Msg: ‘Don’t be evil’: Google denies hitting a donkey with Street View car in Botswana Ben Forrest | Jan 17, 2013 2:46 PM ET More from Ben Forrest | @benthereporter Google MapsGoogle posted these photos online today, showing its Street View vehicle approaching a donkey lying on a road in Botswana. After speculation it was involved in an “unseemly hit and run” with a donkey in Botswana, Google — whose motto is “don’t be evil” — is trying to set the record straight. The company issued a statement Thursday on its Google Maps blog, along with photos of a donkey laying on a road in front of a Google Street View vehicle in Botswana’s Kweneng region. Photos show the donkey lying on its side as the vehicle approaches, then standing on its feet. “As our imagery shows, the donkey was lying on the path – perhaps enjoying a dust bath – before moving safely as our car drove past,” wrote Google Maps product manager Kei Kawai. “I’m pleased to confirm the donkey is alive and well.”

Topic.Title: There Goes Billions More In Revenue: Amazon's $0.69 cent Music Downloads

Message.Msg: Amazon Pulls a Fast One on Apple By Mark Knapp | More Articles January 17, 2013 Page 2 of 2 The Amazon Cloud Player app is free, and some simple math shows that a 30 percent cut of that is $0 for Apple. The next trick comes in how users buy music for Amazon’s app: none of it is purchased in the actual app, so Apple can’t claim its 30 percent share of in-app purchases either. Instead, users can access Amazon’s MP3 store through their iOS device’s Safari browser — or through whatever other browser app they choose — and make the music purchases online, where Apple has no right to a share. The music is then streamed from the cloud on the iOS device without Apple ever seeing a cent of the purchases. To sum up: with Amazon’s music service, users can buy millions of songs, potentially at a discount to iTunes prices, and stream them anywhere, including on their iOS devices, without ever paying Apple a cent. For iOS users choosing this route, iTunes effectively becomes obsolete. As Amazon and Apple continue to battle over the name of their app stores, Amazon has shown Apple that the tech giant can’t always get what it wants. We’ll see if Apple finds a way to bring Amazon to court on this one, but from our perspective, it looks like Amazon has learned how to play the game, and this time might challenge Apple without a lengthy legal battle.

Topic.Title: does anyone have a MS account?...

Message.Msg: January 16, 2013 Apple, Inc. Attractive Risk:Reward into Earnings Strong US demand should translate to iPhone/iPad upside and higher than expected gross margin. C1Q13 seasonality concerns are overblown and several catalysts exist through the remainder of 2013, in our view. We see 6:1 upside to our base case of $714 vs. downside to our bear case of $450. We expect Apple to beat C4Q12 consensus revenue and earnings estimate of $54.6B and $13.35. We believe iPhone shipments drove the upside, as in-cell display and labor constraints eased and iPhone 5 supply improved through the quarter. Recent data from US carriers and our holiday survey suggest demand was stronger than expected. We also see modest upside to our 20M iPad unit forecast (cons. 22M) on the back of iPad mini strength. Strong iPhone sales could drive gross margin upside. We model like-for-like gross margin declines across Apple’s product lines due to higher costs early in product cycles. That said, mix could provide an offsetting tailwind, with every 1M iPhone unit upside adding 10-15 bps to gross margin, all else equal. C1Q13 iPhone shipment concerns are overblown, in our view. As constraints eased, iPhone suppliers built about 13M more units than we model in 2H12. If we add this inventory to the March build plans, we believe Apple can ship 40-45M iPhones in C1Q vs. current market expectations of 35M-40M. So, while it’s reasonable to expect conservative guidance given recent behavior, we believe our current estimates are ultimately achievable. List of potential catalysts growing: 1) iPhone launch in summer 2013 which could include a lower priced version, similar to iPad Mini, 2) new iPads, including iPad Mini with Retina Display around mid-year, 3) expanded carrier partnerships with T-Mobile in the US, NTT Docomo in Japan, and/or China Mobile in 2H13, 4) increased share repurchase (at current levels, every $5B buyback lowers share count by 1%).

Message.Title: APPL shorts fallacy
Message.Msg: There is a ton of talk about the shorts in AAPL, but I don't believe that shorting in AAPL is actually much of an issue at all. Short shares are less than 2% of the float. That is little more than noise. It takes 1 day to cover at current volumes. AAPL is obviously being manipulated in the market, but I think that for the most part the manipulation is not being done to aid short positions. I strongly believe that the manipulation is being done to get better long positions. Institutions, media, hedge funds, etc. have been pulling an all out coordinated attack on AAPL even as they are bullish beyond belief behind closed doors. They want to get themselves into large stock and options positions at the lowest possible price as soon prior to the major positive catalysts that they know are coming. The first catalyst is earnings on the 23rd, so there has been a huge effort to get into AAPL cheap prior to that event. The evidence is clear. Refreshed products, new features, new iOS, iTV, China Mobile, and far more will follow in the coming months. I have no doubt that AAPL will be at new highs by June at the very latest. Big money knows this as well. They could not have asked for a better gift. Why? If AAPL's fall stopped at $600, then the subsequent rise to $800 would be 33%, which is great, but from $500 to $800 is 60%, which is far more amazing. Play the game with them. Get in now with them. Profit with them.

Topic.Title: Android phones outselling iPhones 4 to 1 worldwide...

Message.Msg: Android is an operating system not a Phone!!!!!!!! When people get this fact straight then we can start talking. So how many Phone Makers are using Googles Android Operating system? Samsung...the leader no doubt....and just some notes....Samsung is trying out a Linux based operating system for some of their phones........ Ok so you have Samsung, LG, HTC, and a million other phone makers......and many of these phones running Android are Free....yes you heard it here first......free phone no money.....just 2 year contract......Free......did i say Free... So Google gives the Operating system away to these phone makers for Free...again for free......to be default search engine on phone....unless you are in Asia...Then The default search engine is Bidu...... So Google make very little on giving away Its operating system for Free......a study was released saying Google has possibly made from 500 million to 1 billion off of its operating system...... So What Exactly Does 79% Mean? You are saying Google is Making LOts of money from 79% free operating system? All other Phone makers are Making Big Bucks off Of a Free Operating system? Fact is besides Samsung no other phone company is doing well.....Most other Companies numbers are down...yes down..... When talking about Profit...and selling Phones running a free Android Operating system.....Samsung is Number One...... When talking about Profits as a Company making Phones it is Apple and Samsung........are leading the way If You are talking about Google Androids system making Money it really is not making hardly any money for all the years it has been in existence....And How Many Google/ Motorola phones are being sold? If You want to compare how many phones Google's Motorola brand sells compared to Apple ....or to its competitor Samsung who it gives Android operating system away to for free...then Lets talk....... Otherwise This nonsense of Android Operating system with 79%....is mostly useless?

Topic.Title: SAMSUNG is the present and future

Message.Msg: We were given Galaxy S 3, through work and I despise it with a passion, we have 2 Iphones, one Nokia and one galaxy in our family, when I came home with the New Samsung no one even got off the couch to take look at it, conversley when I bought the Iphone for my daughter the house was filled with screams and recieved numerous hugs, my Son is always sneaking away his moms phone to do face time and what not although he has a phone of his one. The battery on Samsung is horrid, even if you don't use the phone it drains in less than a day and that is the complaint from all the coworkers, Need two hands to dial the numbers. A lot of people like me got sucked in the hype and their wont be a lot of repeat business.

Topic.Title: APPL shorts fallacy

Message.Msg: While I agree that shorting has probably been overstated, I think the options guys are doing a lot of shorting to get the price at the level they want. The lower the price the more puts will expire in the money. And when those puts get struck they will have instantly covered their short at a low price.

Topic.Title: APPLE's "Effect" on INTEL (Intel's earns. down 27%)

Message.Msg: Intel and Microsoft are no longer "Growth Companies". IPAD has reduced the growth for the PC Market. IPAD is growing super-fast and PCs are contracting. Thus INTC and MSFT have too high PE ratios. MSFT has a 14 PE, and INTC's is lower, but as you see INTC even had Revenues go down and earnings plunge 27%. THEIR LOSSES ARE APPLE's GAINS IN SALES.

Topic.Title: APPL shorts fallacy

Message.Msg: "I think the options guys are doing a lot of shorting to get the price at the level they want." Yes, options traders are certainly affecting the price, but the price is not being affected by shorting and certainly no by "a lot of shorting", as you claim. If that were so, then shares short would be far higher. The price is being manipulated, but by and large, not by shorting. The manipulation is psychological. It is mostly all FUD. Shorting is extremely risky in a highly undervalued stock. I believe that most of the so-called shorts are actually closet longs getting in cheap. The numbers just don't support any substantial amount of shorting in AAPL and there is plenty of reason why any sensible person would not be short AAPL, at keast not long term from here.

Topic.Title: now what the F is draggiong it down AH ?

Message.Msg: It is being dragged down by FUD. Fear - uncertainty - Doubt . Do you really believe the earnings will blow the level set by the analyists? How can China Mobile take the iPhone 5 when they do not yet have an infrstrucure to support it. Apple TV is a very far fetched idea that will answer questions that few are asking. Apple is not a bad company and they are masters of quality packaging. But is that all it takes to be the largest corporation in the world ? If any of us REALLY knew what the future portends investment decisions would be simple. But those who choose to ignore all of the warnings and bet the farm to buy in now in 1 years time will look very smart ( and wealthy) or much poorer than they are today. APPL is not dead, but is somewhat injured. Will they recover and be invigorated in the future. Place your bets ladies !!

Topic.Title: BREAKING: ATT SAYS SUBSIDIES STRONGER THAN EXPECTED: MEANS APPLE BLOW AWAY SALES - GET IT .. FANTASTIC

Message.Msg: Talk about misunderstanding. The actual article states that ATT has to PAY so much for subsidies to APPL and other phone vendors that the cash out flow hurts their near term profitabiliy. Look at it this way. If Apple charges appx $600 for iPhone 5 and ATT only sells it for $199 than ATT has to make up a $400 subsidy out of their pocket as soon as they buy the phone. Of course they plan to get that back and more over the term of the next 2 years service contract. But it puts them behind for every one they sell in the short term.

Message.Title: AT&T Warns Of High Margin Smartphones: Stakeholders Debate End Of Apple Subsidy
Message.Msg: AT&T warns of massive Q4 charges NEW YORK | Thu Jan 17, 2013 5:40pm EST Jan 17 (Reuters) - AT&T Inc warned on Thursday that it will take a fourth quarter charge of about $10 billion related to its pension plan and also said results would be hurt by higher than expected smartphone costs and damage due to Superstorm Sandy. The telephone company said the pension charge related to an actuarial loss of about $12 billion, which was partially offset by an asset gain of about $1.9 billion. But despite the gain, it said it lowered its expected long-term rate of return due to the continued uncertainty in the securities markets and the U.S. economy in 2013. It said the pension loss will not affect its operating results or margins.

Message.Msg: No, he understands precisely what he said. T activated more smartphones (interchangeable with cost them more cash flow and aggregate cost of devices purchased) than contemplated in their guidance. The subsidy dollars are something the carriers complain about, but they all know that iPhone users actually use their phones and represent, by far, the biggest source of data plan revenue of all the smartphones they sell. In fact, that is way understated -- AAPL iphones generate more data plan revenue than all other smartphones combined here in the U.S. market. As for your "puts them behind"? THAT is "misunderstanding"... AAPL has been the glorious profit bosster for all of these carriers... just ask China Mobile about losing 7% smartphone share to the other two carriers in China last year as both of their competitors sold iPhones CM doesn't have just yet. CM deal and schedule likely will be shared on the 23rd... Tim has a lot to snuff that day. LOL

Message.Title: Smartphone Subsidy Revolt From Tier 1 Carrier Stakeholders Imminent
Message.Msg: should apple fear a smartphone subsidy revolt from her tier 1 carriers? The iPhone is expensive Wireless carriers have propped sales by subsidizing Subsidies have been good for growth, but are becoming a burden Some carriers are already moving to slow upgrade cycle, others may follow iPhone sales will fall with subsidies how much of an effect will discontinued subsidies have on apples free-falling share price? assuming other companies follow AT&T’s lead in "Subsidy Revolts" , mammoth. i now expect apple’s iPhone sales to nosedive going forward resulting in revenue estimate $billions below street consensus. "How likely is a subsidy revolt? Almost guaranteed at this point, and even if subsidies aren’t dropped altogether, resistance will still have a toll on domestic upgrade sales. Carriers are already pushing against the upgrade cycle -- AT&T is a great example of this. Prior to the launch of the iPhone 4S, AT&T routinely waived the two-year upgrade commitment to allow iPhone users to upgrade after a year, but that is no longer the case. Now users have to wait 20 months to be eligible for an upgrade, tacking eight more months on to the upgrade cycle. Even worse, the carriers are becoming increasingly more outspoken against subsidies, with some going so far as to blame device subsidies for industry woes. Last month T-Mobile’s Chief Marketing Officer Cole Brodman spoke at the GeekWire Summit in Seattle and lamented the distortion caused by subsidies. Internationally subsidies have been even more unwelcome, with several carriers opting to drop subsidies and others speaking publicly about their sustainability." apples new untested management team should have seen this coming. what's wrong with them? what's gone wrong in their lives to make them all so phucked up?

Message.Title: Eye Exam
Message.Msg: I have nothing against AAPL, on the contrary, I wish them well and all AAPL investors a very healthy 2013. But be warned. It's kind of ironic that as I type this there's an ad for lasik staring at me, $699 per eye special. Enough beating around the bush. I'm just going to come out and tell my story. I just got back from my annual eye doctors appointment and half way through the exam my doctor asks me if my wife got me a new tablet or phone for Christmas, to which i replied, "yes, actually an iphone. and I got her a new Ipad 4. You know, the one with the Retinal display." And I could see it in his face, there was some bad news coming. To which, he said, "well, I'd really like you to limit your use to less than an hr. per day. and especially not before you go to bed. You're prescription has gone up a full point. There's still more research to be done on the use of these E-readers but from what I've seen it is absolutely destroying my patients eyes. You are in your mid-thirties. Your eye sight should not be fluctuating this much." So, now I'm a -7.5 prescription. It's debatable what is causing my eyes to go bad. I can definately tell you that I've noticed a huge difference since using these devices. Maybe more and more people will come forward with similiar experiences which will force the industry to address them before they are forced to address them. Good luck!

Topic.Title: LEGENDARY TIMER ON AAPL DEMARK: "THE BOTTOM IS IN" AND 20% RALLY COMING

Message.Msg: The psuchdoc was likely expressing the angry view of many longs here.... but the Demark call was not a one day forecast... instead, it was the long awaited signal for all their pro clients to jump back into the train together, a signal they are ready for... and not the least of which confluences are the recent data points on phones, busy factories, coming agreement on CM news, Tims trip, iPhone market share stats, desperate/errant WSJ "news" that was obviously F up, TMobile jumping aboard the AAPL train, the legitimate analysts re-upping/affirming their BUY ratings and estimates, and clients all telling him they are ready when he is... This is not playtime that the gump shorts posting here think it is. So let's review psychdocs and anyone else's confusion. How many people with more than an 8th education would draw the conclusion that his "amazing call lasted one whole day"? Take a deep breath and relax... if you are long, the grimness is over. The Demark call was not for up $20 day one and down $2 the next... It was for a final bottom getting put in yesterday or today (correctly called), followed by a move of 22% or so higher over the next two weeks (that was the math back to $600/share from when he said that). Might the shorts squirm more tomorrow? No doubt -- their ox is gored and the hedged shorts have already covered in... from here, if you are unhedged short, long some puts or short some calls, you are the bagholder into next week's conference call. For the unhedged shorts and put buyers spewing nonsense here for the last month? Time for them to line up and be ready to dive under a string of buses head first. The RIP to $600 within a week with leave us breathless and them hosed. PT $800 by EOY (we've been right annually since $90/share)... and Tim already told everyone: "Don't bet against AAPL."

Analyst Next Q: When do you see this trend of Apple's IPAD and Mac line of Computers taking market share from Windows Computer ending? INTC Answer: "Next Question".

Topic.Title: THIS TURD IS GOING TO $250 BY YEAR END!! Lol

Message.Msg: $145B or so of cash as of today doesn't "mean anything"? Say what? Are you seriously suggesting they are going to go from say $45B of after tax, dividend and share repurchase cash flow from operations this year plus the value of exercise options this year to what, zero? RIMM went to S in a handbag in two years (not criticaldshits suggested 11 months) for several reasons. RIMM had 1. a lot less cash, 2. debt to service, 3. bloated operating expenses, 4. a S operating system that wasn't so special secure after all they learned the hard way,5. a whole line of quickly antiquated top to bottom end phones no one wanted and on which the user got a lousy experience, and 6. had no ecosystem of any kind three years ago when their slide began in earnest and they still don't. The RIMM 10 is DOA, even if they don't know it yet. Ignoring the gumptards here, ask anyone who has an iPhone 4 or 4s or 5 how they feel about their iPhones. They will tell you they love it as if they are talking about their boyfriend/girlfriend and, whether they think about it or not, they will be part of the AAPL ecosystem for years and years to come. Switching to an Android phone (no way will anyone buy the MSFT phones after trying the lunky, heavy, awkward to hold and turdy in your pocket and head) after having an iPhone would be like belonging to L.A. Country club and then being relegatedto playing something terrible such as the Long beach muni every weekend. Just plain intolerably awful.

Topic.Title: Anyone remember January 2012 right before earnings?

Message.Msg: This year is very similar to last year. And just like then, if you look past the noise you could see that the quarter was going to be a monster. Last Q1 had an extra month in it, Steve Jobs died and there was massive sympathy buying of Apple products, and usage studies pointed to large market gain in the much panned 4S. This year doesn't have the extra week but every clue points to big earnings. Apple's US market share is over 50% for the first time. AT&T and Verizon have announced better than expected smartphone sales. The iPhone 5 rollout was far quicker and even included a week in China that brought in around 5M. Apple suppliers are announcing huge sales, China exports are high and the US GDP got at least a .5% bump from the iPhone. And to top it all of, analysts are sandbagging and actually have earnings dropping from last year. The beat will be massive. To top it off, Q2 guidance will be way better than expected. For whatever reason analysts are forgetting about the Chinese New Year. Last year Q2 was nearly as good as Q1 and Apple stumbled badly in China that quarter. This year they are ready and have even added the mini which has been met with "insatiable demand". Plus Apple offering credit to buyers. Next quarter will be huge.

Topic.Title: AT&T Large charge announcement bodes well for Apple-- Iphones sold High.

Message.Msg: Good find! From article" AT&T said its wireless profit will also be reduced by higher than expected sales of smartphones such as the Apple Inc iPhone in the quarter. Because AT&T and its rivals tend to pay a hefty subsidy for each smartphone they sell, high phone sales put pressure on wireless profit margins. They pay subsidies so they can offer phone discounts to consumers who commit to long-term contracts. AT&T said on Thursday that it sold 10.2 million smartphones in the quarter, which would imply sales of about 26.9 million for 2012 up from its December forecast for 26 million. AT&T had said at the beginning of 2013 that it hoped to keep smartphone sales at around 25 million for the year."

Topic.Title: Did anyone notice that Al Gore exercised his apple director options

Message.Msg: The taxable gain is the difference between the exercise price and the market price 485 on the day of exercise. The lower the price the lower the taxes paid. If the stock were to go up the taxes would be greater or down the taxes Would be less . If I recall the tax rules correctly. Exercise of options is not generally covered by inside information rules and generally people try to pick the lowet price possible for the day of exercise to minimize the gain. Pure speculation but......and maybe the Directors are kept out of the loop.....who knows?

Message.Title: Interesting Statistic
Message.Msg: For the past 3 Q1 earnings reports (past 3 years), AAPL has beaten EPS guidance by an average of 62%. If they were to continue this trend, the EPS would be $19 per share. Obviously, this is unrealistic, but interesting nonetheless. If they come in at half of their average, this would equate to and EPS of $15.29 which I would take any day of the week. Three more trading days and I can stop crunching numbers.

Message.Title: Wipro, whose customers include Apple Inc and BP PLC posted an 18 percent gain better-than-expected earnings.
Message.Msg: Wipro, whose customers include Apple Inc and BP PLC , said net profit for the three months ended December rose to 17.16 billion rupees ($316 million) from 14.56 billion rupees a year earlier. That compares with the average estimate of 16.45 billion rupees in a poll of 20 analysts, according to Thomson Reuters data.
